Review: Encanto

18/03/2022

Sophia Andrews Gamarra reviews Encanto - a charming, yet run-of-the-mill addition to the Disney canon

Image by Walt Disney Pictures

By Kyle Boulton

Encanto is Disneyâ€™s latest animated offering â€“ a tale of a Colombian family living in a magical house, which has bestowed upon each of them a superpower. The protagonist is Mirabel Madrigal, the only child who was mysteriously not given a superhuman trait. But when the â€œencantoâ€ is threatened, itâ€™s down to her to save it.

Even for those who rarely watched Disney films as children, this probably sounds familiar. While Encanto represents a welcome change in Disneyâ€™s depiction of foreign cultures, it is, at its core, a Disney film.

Mirabel, the only â€œnormalâ€ one in a family of X-Men, is a classic fish-out-of-water. Despite her outwardly manic cheerfulness, she feels inadequate and side-lined by everyone around her. Yet she soon realises the magic of their Casita is fading, and seeks out her lost uncle Bruno, whose prophecies hold the key to saving it.

She repairs her strained relationship with her â€œperfectâ€ sister Isabela, which revitalises Casita's magic. But then she comes into conflict with Abuela, who, due to her lack of a superpower, suspects her of being responsible for the magic fading. At this moment, it appears the magic will disappear forever, yet it is their reconciliation and the familyâ€™s new-found respect for Mirabel that renews it. And they all live happily ever after.

And thatâ€™s the plot of Encanto. The only problem is, itâ€™s been done before.

In an op-ed for Inside the Magic, Nathaniel Eker outlines a Disney filmâ€™s typical narrative structure:

Meet the hero (usually a fish out of water). Hero expresses discontent with the current situation (usually through song). Hero meets a mentor figure or deuteragonist. Hero begins to succeed and often finds love. Villain momentarily prospers. Villain loses, hero lives happily ever after.

Encanto, despite lacking a villain and a love interest for its protagonist, hits every single one of these beats.

Now, you could argue: if it ainâ€™t broke, donâ€™t fix it. The stranglehold Disney has over childrenâ€™s media across the globe is undeniably monolithic. Time and again, their stories resonate beyond cultural borders. Also, Disney arenâ€™t the only one to rehash a useful formula for storytelling. This narrative structure echoes Joseph Campbellâ€™s â€œHeroâ€™s Journeyâ€, a framework applicable to both ancient myths and modern stories.

But Encanto has little to offer beyond this formula. The plot is short, with narrative turns quickly unleashed before the audience has a chance to feel any tension from them. The song â€˜We Donâ€™t Talk About Brunoâ€™ is a chart-topping hit, and unsurprisingly so. In the songâ€™s climax, Lin-Manuel Miranda effortlessly blends each characterâ€™s parts to create a polyphonic outro thatâ€™s almost painfully catchy. But in the film itself, all this mystery the song creates around Bruno quickly dissipates, when itâ€™s revealed heâ€™s actually an awkward-but-lovable misfit. Then, before you know it, heâ€™s accepted into the community again and the filmâ€™s over.

Encantoâ€™s lack of a villain is a welcome shift for Disney. It doesnâ€™t talk down to children by presenting a black-and-white view of the world that climaxes in the good-looking heroes rewarded and the ugly villains punished.

Yet the film strictly adheres to Disneyâ€™s narrative formula, while removing the few elements that gave Disneyâ€™s old films any stakes. It has room for complex themes, such as intergenerational trauma, but its tight plotting does not allow them much significance in the narrative. The characters argue, apologise, then have a dance party.

Many have praised Disney for its faithful representation of Colombian culture. In Encanto, the architecture and natural landscapes resemble real-life towns and cities, albeit in fluorescent technicolour. The soundtrack is filled with distinctly Colombian rhythms and instrumentation. The dialogue has smatterings of Spanish, but enough that it is still understandable to a non-Spanish-speaking audience. Its premise has faint, child-friendly echoes of Gabriel Garcia Marquezâ€™s 100 Years of Solitude.

Encanto has many cultural elements familiar to one of Colombian (or even broadly Latino) heritage, and itâ€™s refreshing to see a film that presents them as normal, rather than exotic. But Encanto is a standard Disney film with a new lick of paint. The filmâ€™s tone is relentlessly cheery. Mirabel is the quirky, energised heroine, a stock character like Frozenâ€™s Anna, or Tangledâ€™s Rapunzel. There is slapstick comedy, wacky side-characters and adorable children. The film ends with the characters encouraged to be themselves, that theyâ€™re special just the way they are.

The film is beautiful to look at, the performances are enthusiastic, and it left me with a bit of a fuzzy feeling in my stomach. Itâ€™s a nice Disney film, but a Disney film is all it is.
